subject: RE: [junit] New Classes when refactoring
msgSnippet: ... In short, I create a test if the test will build confidence. For example, in the case of an extract class refactoring where the new class is used solely
messageBody:
--- "Cox, Randy" <randy.cox@...> wrote:
> Mike
>
> That is how I read Fowler's comments. That seems to break the
> pattern of a
> test class
> for each class. When if every do you go back and create a test class
> that
> just tests the
> new class?
>

In short, I create a test if the test will build confidence.

For example, in the case of an extract class refactoring where the new
class is used solely through the interface of the original class
(facade), then I'll rely on the existing tests for the original class.
Writing an additional test for the class being used exclusively behind
the facade doesn't build confidence, in my opinion, so it doesn't pass
the cost-benefit test. If the new class evolves such that it's used by
multiple classes and takes on more responsibility, then I may create a
separate test for it.

Prior to developing the facade I would have created a test (a la
test-first design) as a way to build confidence through the
design/development process. However, I don't subscribe to the view
that all classes must have a matching test class. Rather, I strive to
have all classes tested either directly or indirectly through tests,
regarless of the location of those tests.

Mike
